title:
Multiplicities in the trace cocharacter sequence of two $4\times 4$
  matrices

title_detail.value:
Multiplicities in the trace cocharacter sequence of two $4\times 4$
  matrices

summary:
We find explicitly the generating functions of the multiplicities in the pure
and mixed trace cocharacter sequences of two $4\times 4$ matrices over a field
of characteristic 0. We determine the asymptotic behavior of the multiplicities
and show that they behave as polynomials of 14th degree.

summary_detail.value:
We find explicitly the generating functions of the multiplicities in the pure
and mixed trace cocharacter sequences of two $4\times 4$ matrices over a field
of characteristic 0. We determine the asymptotic behavior of the multiplicities
and show that they behave as polynomials of 14th degree.

author: Georgi K. Genov
fulltext:
arXiv:math/0502373v1 [math.RA] 17 Feb 2005

MULTIPLICITIES IN THE TRACE COCHARACTER SEQUENCE
OF TWO 4 × 4 MATRICES
VESSELIN DRENSKY AND GEORGI K. GENOV
Abstract. We find explicitly the generating functions of the multiplicities in
the pure and mixed trace cocharacter sequences of two 4×4 matrices over a field
of characteristic 0. We determine the asymptotic behavior of the multiplicities
and show that they behave as polynomials of 14th degree.

Introduction
Let us fix an arbitrary field F of characteristic 0 and two integers n, d ≥ 2.
Consider the d generic n × n matrices X1 , . . . , Xd . We denote by C the pure trace
algebra generated by the traces of all products tr(Xi1 * * * Xik ), and by T the mixed
trace algebra generated by X1 , . . . , Xd and C, regarding the elements of C as scalar
matrices. The algebra C coincides with the algebra of invariants of the general
linear group GLn (F ) acting by simultaneous conjugation on d matrices of size n.
The algebra T is the algebra of matrix concominants under a suitable action of
GLn (F ). See e.g. the books [12], [11], or [5] as a background on C and T and their
numerous applications.
The algebras C and T are graded by multidegree. The Hilbert (or Poincaré)
series of C is
X
H(C) = H(C, t1 , . . . , td ) =
dim C (k) tk11 * * * tkdd ,
where C (k) is the homogeneous component of multidegree k = (k1 , . . . , kd ). In the
same way one defines the Hilbert series of T . These series are symmetric functions
and decompose as infinite linear combinations of Schur functions Sλ (t1 , . . . , td ),
X
H(C) =
mλ (C)Sλ (t1 , . . . , td ),

where λ = (λ1 , . . . , λd ) is a partition in not more than d parts, and the mλ (C)s are
nonnegative integers which are 0 if d > n2 and λn2 +1 > 0. A similar expression
holds for the Hilbert series of T . The multiplicities mλ (C) and mλ (T ) have important combinatorial properties and ring theoretical meanings. In particular, they are
equal to the multiplicities of the irreducible Sk -characters in the sequences of pure
and mixed trace cocharacters, respectively, and give estimates for the multiplicities
in the "ordinary" cocharacters of the polynomial identities of the n × n matrix
algebra.

2000 Mathematics Subject Classification. Primary: 16R30; Secondary: 05E05.
Key words and phrases. trace rings, invariant theory, matrix invariants, matrix concominants,
algebras with polynomial identities, Hilbert series, symmetric functions, Schur functions.
Partially supported by Grant MM-1106/2001 of the Bulgarian Foundation for Scientific
Research.
1

 2

VESSELIN DRENSKY AND GEORGI GENOV

The multiplicities of mλ (C) and mλ (T ) are explicitly known in very few cases.
For n = 2 and any d, Formanek [9] showed that
mλ (T ) = (λ1 − λ2 + 1)(λ2 − λ3 + 1)(λ3 − λ4 + 1),
if λ = (λ1 , λ2 , λ3 , λ4 ), and mλ (T ) = 0 if λ5 6= 0. He also found a more complicated
expression for the multiplicities in the Hilbert series of C. With some additional
work, based on representation theory of symmetric and general linear groups, these
results can be also derived from the paper by Procesi [14]. The Hilbert series of C
and T can be expressed as multiple integrals, evaluated by Teranishi [15, 16] for C
and n = 3, 4 and d = 2. Van den Bergh [17] suggested graph theoretical methods for
calculation of H(C) and H(T ). Berele and Stembridge [3] calculated the Hilbert
series of C and T for n = 3, d ≤ 3 and for n = 4, d = 2, correcting also some
typographical errors in the expression of H(C) for n = 4 and d = 2 in [16]. Using
the Hilbert series of C, n = 3, d = 2, Berele [1] found an asymptotic expression of
m(λ1 ,λ2 ) (C). The explicit form of the generating function of m(λ1 ,λ2 ) (C) was found
by the authors of the present paper [6] correcting also a technical error in [1]. Later
they [7] suggested a method to find the coefficients of the Schur functions in the
expansion of a class of rational symmetric functions in two variables. Jointly with
Valenti [8] they have used the expression of the Hilbert series H(T ) found by Berele
and Stembridge [3] and have calculated explicitly the multiplicities m(λ1 ,λ2 ) (T ) for
n = 3 and d = 2.
The purpose of the present paper is to calculate, for n = 4 and d = 2, the
generating functions of m(λ1 ,λ2 ) (C) and m(λ1 ,λ2 ) (T ). In principle, this allows to give
explicit expressions for the multiplicities. Since the formulas are quite complicated,
we prefer to give the asymptotics only, as in [1]. It turns out that the multiplicities
m(λ1 ,λ2 ) (C) and m(λ1 ,λ2 ) (T ) behave as polynomials of degree 14 in λ1 and λ2 . As
in [8], our approach is to apply the methods of [7] to the explicit form of the Hilbert
series of C and T found in [3]. As in [8], results of Formanek [9, 10] imply that the
values of the multiplicities mλ (M4 (F )) for λ = (λ1 , . . . , λ16 ) coincide with these of
m(λ1 −λ16 ,λ2 −λ16 ) (T ) when λ3 = * * * = λ16 ≥ 2.
Carbonara, Carini and Remmel [4] determined, for any n, the behaviour of
mλ (C), when λ2 , . . . , λn2 is fixed and λ1 sufficiently large. Our results give more
detail, for n = 4, in this direction. A general result of Berele [2] describes the
multiplicities of Schur functions for the class of rational symmetric functions with
denominators which are products of binomials 1 − tk11 * * * tkdd , in any number of
variables. It covers the Hilbert series of relatively free algebras and pure and mixed
trace algebras. Again, our results give some detail in the partial case which we
consider in this paper.
1. Preliminaries
We refer to the book by Macdonald [13] for a background on theory of symmetric
functions. We shortly summarize the facts we need for our exposition. We consider
the algebra Sym[[x, y]] of formal power series which are symmetric functions in two
variables over C. Every element f (x, y) ∈ Sym[[x, y]] can be expressed in a unique
way as an infinite linear combination
X
f (x, y) =
m(λ)Sλ (x, y),
λ

m(λ) ∈ C is the multiplicity of Sλ (x, y) in the decomposition of f (x, y). The Schur
function Sλ (x, y) has the form

The following theorem from [7] describes the symmetric functions with rational
multiplicity series and gives hints how to calculate the multiplicity series for such
functions.
Theorem 1. The multiplicity series of f (x, y) ∈ Sym[[x, y]] is rational if and only
if f (x, y) has the form
f (x, y) =

p(x, xy) + p(y, xy)

The polynomial h(t, v) can be found from (1) by the method of unknown coefficients. The calculations can be simplified if we know the decomposition of q(x, z).

2. Main Results
In the sequel we fix n = 4 and d = 2 and denote, respectively, by C and T the
pure and mixed trace algebras generated by two generic 4 × 4 matrices X and Y .
We replace the variables t1 , t2 with x, y and denote e2 = xy. The Hilbert series of
C and T found by Berele and Stembridge [3] are

Proof. Direct calculations, which we have performed using Maple, show that, replacing the expression (4) of mC instead of M ′ (f ) in the right hand side of (1) we
obtain hC from (3). This completes the proof, because of the injectivity of M ′ . We
want to say a couple of words how we have calculated mC . Applying Theorem 1
we know that mC is of the form
mC (t, v) =

r(t, v)
,
q(t, v)

where r(t, v) ∈ C(v)[t] and
q(t, v) = (1 − t)4 (1 + t)2 (1 + t + t2 )(1 + t2 )(1 − vt)2 (1 − vt2 ).
Theorem 1 gives also that degt r ≤ degt q − 2 = 12. Decomposing mC as a sum
of elementary fractions with coefficients from C(v) and denominators which are
powers of 1 − t, 1 + t, 1 + t + t2 , 1 + t2 , 1 − vt, and 1 − vt2 , we obtain that mC
is as in (4). In order to calculate the coefficients αi , βi , γi , δi , εi , φi , we replace hC
and mC in the left and right hind sides of (1), respectively. Replacing y with e2 /x,
we apply Lemma 2 for K = C(e2 ) and ξ a zero of the denominator q(x, e2 ). In this
way we obtain the coefficients of the denominators of highest degree of 1 − t, 1 + t,
and 1 − vt. Replacing the obtained coefficients in (4), we calculate step by step all
the coefficients αi , βi , εi . The coefficients γi , δi , φi , i = 0, 1, are obtained using both
the zeros of 1 + t + t2 , 1 + t2 and 1 − vt2 .

Theorems 3 and 4 give the explicit (but very complicated) form of the multiplicities mλ (C) and mλ (T ) for any λ = (λ1 , λ2 ). We prefer to present the results in
more compressed, but more convenient form.

The following theorem is the main result of our paper. It is in the spirit of the
description of the multiplicities of the pure trace algebra of two 3 × 3 matrices given
by Berele [1].
